lines.text: Enter LADY MACBETH and a Servant

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Ay, madam, but returns again tonight.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Say to the king, I would attend his leisure For a few words.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Noughts had, alls spent, Where our desire is got without content: Tis safer to be that which we destroy Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy. How now, my lord! why do you keep alone, Of sorriest fancies your companions making, Using those thoughts which should indeed have died With them they think on Things without all remedy Should be without regard: whats done is done.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: We have scotchd the snake, not killd it: Shell close and be herself, whilst our poor malice Remains in danger of her former tooth. But let the frame of things disjoint, both the worlds suffer, Ere we will eat our meal in fear and sleep In the affliction of these terrible dreams That shake us nightly: better be with the dead, Whom we, to gain our peace, have sent to peace, Than on the torture of the mind to lie In restless ecstasy. Duncan is in his grave After lifes fitful fever he sleeps well Treason has done his worst: nor steel, nor poison, Malice domestic, foreign levy, nothing, Can touch him further.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Come on Gentle my lord, sleek oer your rugged looks Be bright and jovial among your guests tonight.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: So shall I, love and so, I pray, be you: Let your remembrance apply to Banquo Present him eminence, both with eye and tongue: Unsafe the while, that we Must lave our honours in these flattering streams, And make our faces vizards to our hearts, Disguising what they are.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: O, full of scorpions is my mind, dear wife! Thou knowst that Banquo, and his Fleance, lives.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: But in them natures copys not eterne.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Theres comfort yet they are assailable Then be thou jocund: ere the bat hath flown His cloisterd flight, ere to black Hecates summons The shardborne beetle with his drowsy hums Hath rung nights yawning peal, there shall be done A deed of dreadful note.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest chuck, Till thou applaud the deed. Come, seeling night, Scarf up the tender eye of pitiful day And with thy bloody and invisible hand Cancel and tear to pieces that great bond Which keeps me pale! Light thickens and the crow Makes wing to the rooky wood: Good things of day begin to droop and drowse While nights black agents to their preys do rouse. Thou marvellst at my words: but hold thee still Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill. So, prithee, go with me.
